question: 1. Derive the no-arbitrage condition (12.4.13b) for the type II firm from its objective function (12.4.12).
merged_original_background_text: This section covers the optimization problem of the representative firm of type II, which transforms output into capital and earns revenues by renting capital to the type I firm. The firm's decisions are subject to a technological constraint and no-arbitrage conditions, leading to equilibrium pricing relationships.
merged_original_paper_extracted_texts: The type II firm maximizes $$-p_{k0}k_{0}^{I I}+\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\sum_{s^{t}}\left\{r_{t}^{0}(s^{t})k_{t}^{I I}\left(s^{t-1}\right)-q_{t}^{0}(s^{t})x_{t}(s^{t})\right\}$$ subject to $$k_{t+1}^{I I}\left(s^{t}\right)=\left(1-\delta\right)k_{t}^{I I}\left(s^{t-1}\right)+x_{t}\left(s^{t}\right).$$

The type II firm’s objective function can be written as $$\begin{array}{l}{{{k_{0}^{I I}}\left\{-p_{k0}+r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right\}+\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\sum_{s^{t}}k_{t+1}^{I I}\left(s^{t}\right)}}\ {{.\quad\left\{-q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)+\displaystyle\sum_{s^{t+1}\mid s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right]\right\},}}\end{array}$$ where the firm’s profit is a linear function of investments in capital.

In an equilibrium, $k_{0}^{I I}$ and $k_{t+1}^{I I}(s^{t})$ are strictly positive and finite so each expression in curly brackets in (12.4.12) must equal zero and hence equilibrium prices must satisfy $$p_{k0}=r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right),$$ $$q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)=\sum_{s^{t+1}|s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right].$$
question_context:
The type II firm maximizes $$-p_{k0}k_{0}^{I I}+\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\sum_{s^{t}}\left\{r_{t}^{0}(s^{t})k_{t}^{I I}\left(s^{t-1}\right)-q_{t}^{0}(s^{t})x_{t}(s^{t})\right\}$$ subject to $$k_{t+1}^{I I}\left(s^{t}\right)=\left(1-\delta\right)k_{t}^{I I}\left(s^{t-1}\right)+x_{t}\left(s^{t}\right).$$
The type II firm’s objective function can be written as $$\begin{array}{l}{{{k_{0}^{I I}}\left\{-p_{k0}+r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right\}+\displaystyle\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\sum_{s^{t}}k_{t+1}^{I I}\left(s^{t}\right)}}\ {{.\quad\left\{-q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)+\displaystyle\sum_{s^{t+1}\mid s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right]\right\},}}\end{array}$$ where the firm’s profit is a linear function of investments in capital.
In an equilibrium, $k_{0}^{I I}$ and $k_{t+1}^{I I}(s^{t})$ are strictly positive and finite so each expression in curly brackets in (12.4.12) must equal zero and hence equilibrium prices must satisfy $$p_{k0}=r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right),$$ $$q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)=\sum_{s^{t+1}|s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right].$$

This section covers the optimization problem of the representative firm of type II, which transforms output into capital and earns revenues by renting capital to the type I firm. The firm's decisions are subject to a technological constraint and no-arbitrage conditions, leading to equilibrium pricing relationships.

model_evaluation_result.model_answer: Step 1: Start with the type II firm's objective function in its rewritten form, where profit is linear in investments in capital. The rewritten objective function is: $$k_{0}^{I I}\left\{-p_{k0}+r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right\}+\sum_{t=0}^{\infty}\sum_{s^{t}}k_{t+1}^{I I}\left(s^{t}\right)\left\{-q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)+\sum_{s^{t+1}\mid s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right]\right\}.$$ Step 2: Note that in equilibrium, $k_{0}^{I I}$ and $k_{t+1}^{I I}(s^{t})$ are strictly positive and finite. For the firm's optimization problem to have a solution, the terms in curly brackets must equal zero (otherwise, the firm could increase profits infinitely by choosing $k_{0}^{I I}$ or $k_{t+1}^{I I}(s^{t})$ to be arbitrarily large or small). Step 3: Set the first curly bracket term to zero to derive the no-arbitrage condition for $p_{k0}$: $$-p_{k0}+r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)=0 \implies p_{k0}=r_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)+q_{0}^{0}\left(s_{0}\right)\left(1-\delta\right).$$ Step 4: Set the second curly bracket term to zero to derive the no-arbitrage condition for $q_{t}^{0}(s^{t})$: $$-q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)+\sum_{s^{t+1}\mid s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right]=0 \implies q_{t}^{0}\left(s^{t}\right)=\sum_{s^{t+1}|s^{t}}\left[r_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)+q_{t+1}^{0}\left(s^{t+1}\right)\left(1-\delta\right)\right].$$ Step 5: The second condition (for $q_{t}^{0}(s^{t})$) is the no-arbitrage condition (12.4.13b) for the type II firm, derived from its objective function.
